ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: - Understanding theories and concepts behind the sociology of education
A greater understanding of the sociology of education

I learned how to read a large amount of readings each week and manage my time to be able to complete every task. This class also helped me gain knowledge about differences in educational experiences, which is really important for me to keep in mind in the future.

In this course, I learned a survey of sociological analyses of education. Topics that stand out to me are more classical social theory on education and race, which we put in conversation with each other. We also read books from contemporary social theorists who conducted different ethnographies of schools.

knowledge: lots about sociological issues in education, info about careers in sociology 
skills: summarizing large sections of writing, how to write a book review

I learned about the fundamentals of the Sociology of Education. It's a broad topic, but the class gave a good introduction to all the thinkers, writers, and subject areas of the matter. I also learned how to be a better social sciences reasearcher.

Learned about sociology, academia, and education inequality.

Heard about how hard it is to become a tenured professor (not sure if this is relevant to the class topic)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: 
- Interesting concepts
- I like the format of dividing the course materials and presenting
Weaknesses:
- Can be hard to stay on top of everything

Strengths: good broad overview of the field
Weaknesses: not enough discussions during class

I loved the guest lecturers and would have loved to have more speakers. The discussions were incredibly interesting, I just would have liked to spend less time listening to and writing the summaries of the readings.

A strength of the course is that we got to have multiple authors from the course material speak with the class, and that the course material really did cover a lot of different topics in the sociology of education. Breadth is a definite strength!

Strengths: Class had a good concept

Weakness: Not enough room for discussion, professor would go on too many irrelevant tangents
Could be more discussion-oriented and less time spent presenting summaries. I liked the guest speakers
One strength is that the readings were varied and interesting. The syllabus covered a lot of ground. However, the reading load was rather heavy at times.

+: interesting topics, Prof. Kao is knowledgable

-: although this was a seminar, there was a lack of discussion and real engagement with the materials; the summary assignment for readings felt repetitive and did not give room for critical thinking; class often went on tangents 

i would recommend taking away or changing the summary assignments to a discussion thread for the class and to increase class time for discussion among students.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I think it was good to learn more about education in terms of reproducing inequity, disparities, and theories.
I would recommend this course if they are interested in learning more about the determinants of educational outcomes

I would recommend this course to another student because I feel like I learned a lot about the education system and different demographic factors that affect education, information that I will be sure to use in the future.

I would recommend this course only to a student who has a background in either sociology or education studies and who doesn't mind having a really heavy reading load. Unfortunately, we did not discuss the readings much, but the course is nice for someone who wants to read material on education.

Only if they need it or are really interested in education or sociology. It was very different to what I thought it would be like after the first class. Grace Kao is not very flexible as a professor, which makes it stressful if you have to miss class for any reason (pretty much if you have lots of other things going on in your life that are not academic-related, which describes most Yale students).
I would recommend it, especially to those interested in either sociology or education.
I would recommend this class to someone who wanted to get an overview to socioed but caution them that the class does not function like a seminar.
